Ask HN: How do you discuss interesting research online?
text:
Suppose you find a nice, interesting research paper online somewhere (say arxiv) and you’d love to find other people who read the same paper to discuss it a bit (even if briefly). Maybe you want to share a flaw you found, or maybe it made you think of a new idea, or you want to talk about its interesting use of methods, or even advertise that you did something similar. How would you do that nowadays?

I expect answers such as: my own research group (too limited/potential echo chamber); researchgate (too ”social network” for my taste, no focus, bloated interface); twitter (not even sure where to start?).

Any other ideas?

Show HN: New Moderation Model for UGC and AI Generated Content
text:
Hi Everyone,

At Skymel, we're excited about developing a combination of on-device and cloud-based AI solutions that will reduce latency, lower costs, and enhance consumer engagement.

As a first step, we've developed a model that can identify both safe and unsafe content, as well as artificial images. Given the rapid growth of AI-generated content, we anticipate that companies will face significant challenges in keeping their platforms safe for users, and we believe that our approach is well-positioned to tackle these problems head-on.

Ask HN: Self-Employed folks, are you earning a living wage from your work?
text:
This is a very vague question but it was prompted after reading about this [1] topic yesterday. The author mentioned it took them 5 years to get to $1000/month.

This made me think about a distinction, although I'm having trouble putting my finger on it.

One kind of a self employed person is a product developer/seller and the other is selling services/consulting. (And I'm sure there are more if we further down.)

To me, it seems like 'The odds of success are very low for a startup' and other related wisdom is usually referring to the product based solo entrepreneurs.

I'm curious to know what are the experiences and how hard is it to earn a decent* income doing the consulting/freelancing/contract based 'renting out my time' approach?

I'm hoping to hear someone insights into people's experiences, and possibly comparisons to going down the product path. The end goal would be to work for yourself.

* - `decent` could be defined as within 50% of the income you could earn by working for someone else. It's vague, and not really a constraint for this discussion.

[1] Five years of indie hacking https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35036871

Thank you for any comments and experiences.

Ask HN: Google Account Recovery
text:
I know this gets brought up occasionally; but I've been locked out of a google account that belongs to me for about half a decade.

It is linked to another google account that I actively use, I'm not sure if I remember the password to the lost account(since google won't let me into the account). But I routinely use the linked account.

I'm denied access to my account on the grounds that I'm logging in from an unfamiliar IP/device, however my parents moved to a new home when I'd gone to college, and since I was at college I no longer had access to the main IP address that I was logging into it from.

My browser settings have been set to auto clear cookies on close for as long as I can remember. So it didn't recognize any of the devices I routinely use to access it.

I'm trying to get access to that account so that I can deal with what I have to, and then delete the account.

What recourse do I actually have for the same? I've recently switched to Posteo since I never want to be held hostage like this by Google ever again, but it doesn't resolve my original issue where I'm being unfairly locked out of my account because google doesn't trust me...

Literally any help would be a godsend.

Are you worried about your infosec with ChatGPT, or other AI apps?
text:
TLDR:

1. Are you worried about sensitive or restricted data making it to AI providers from employee errors or integration mistakes?

2. If so, how are you stopping sensitive data from reaching your AI providers?

We’ve heard concerns at two levels of seriousness:

1. Legally controlled data:

- PHI (i.e. health information), SSNs, anything Attorney Client privileged, etc. Here, no matter how good the MSA you have in place is or how reputable the AI provider, you legally cannot share that data.

2. Sensitive/Restricted Internal data:

- Strategic planning documents, financials, customer records, trade secrets, meeting transcripts for sensitive meetings e.t.c. Here, with the right agreements in place with the provider, it’s probably ok to share, but only if all usage is going through a centralized account with firm agreements in place, and even then, you want to be careful.

Now it’s easy to have a rule that says “Don’t put this into AI”, but with employees everywhere using AI for things like meeting notes summarization, a user can just paste an hour long meeting transcript, not realize it has sensitive data in, and then worst case scenario when the provider retrains their model, it puts that information in the hands of other customers/users.

If you have any legally controlled data, or your employees use tools like Chat GPT on personal accounts that haven’t opted out of model training, this seems to be a serious risk.

For example: one of our prospects was using Vowel.com, whose terms of service state they can train models on top of your meeting recordings, with practically 0 restrictions. This could easily end up creating ‘completions’ that regurgitated customer names, strategies, even financials to other companies. Vowel don’t have to be malicious to do this - at scaled usage of AI across many vendors: we think this is inevitable. That’s why security conscious companies like [REDACTED] turned off Chat GPT today.

Curious how HN is thinking about maintaining infosec in the new scary world of AI!?
